easy.text: The sun rises in the east and sets in the west. This is a daily occurrence that brings light and warmth to our world. Many people enjoy watching the sunrise or sunset.
Water is essential for all living things. Humans need to drink water every day to stay healthy. Plants also require water to grow and produce food.
Exercise is important for maintaining a healthy body. Walking, running, and swimming are good forms of exercise. Regular activity helps strengthen muscles and improve mood.

medium.text: Globalization has increased interconnectedness among countries through trade and technology. This exchange influences cultures, economies, and politics worldwide, creating both opportunities and challenges.
Renewable energy sources, such as solar and wind power, are crucial for sustainable development. They reduce reliance on fossil fuels and help mitigate the effects of climate change.
Education empowers individuals by providing knowledge and critical thinking skills. Access to quality education can break cycles of poverty and foster social and economic progress.

hard.text: The philosophical concept of existentialism explores individual freedom and the absence of inherent meaning in life. Thinkers like Sartre argued that humans must create their own purpose through choices and actions.
Quantum mechanics challenges classical physics by introducing principles like superposition and entanglement. These phenomena are fundamental to understanding particles at subatomic scales.
The Renaissance was a pivotal period marked by a revival of art, science, and humanism. It bridged the Middle Ages and modern history, catalyzing advancements in various fields across Europe.

easy.text: Printing 'Hello, World!' is often the first program you write. It teaches you how to display text on the screen. This simple step is the start of learning any programming language.
To add two numbers in code, you use the plus sign (+). For example, 5 + 3 equals 8. This basic math operation is common in many programs.
An 'if' statement lets your program make decisions. It checks if a condition is true, like 'is the score greater than 10?'. If yes, it runs a specific block of code.

medium.text: Recursion is a technique where a function calls itself to solve a smaller instance of a problem. A classic example is calculating a factorial, where n! = n * (n-1)!. It requires a well-defined base case to terminate.

A hash map stores key-value pairs and provides average O(1) time complexity for lookups. It uses a hash function to compute an index into an array of buckets. Handling collisions is a key implementation detail, often done via chaining or open addressing.

Asynchronous programming allows a program to initiate a long-running task and remain responsive to other events. Promises or async/await syntax in JavaScript are used to handle operations like fetching data from an API without blocking the main execution thread.

hard.text: Tail call optimization (TCO) is a compiler technique where a recursive function call in tail position is executed without increasing the call stack. This transforms recursion into iteration, preventing stack overflow. It is part of the ES2015 specification but remains inconsistently implemented across JavaScript engines.

Monads in functional programming are a design pattern used to handle program-wide concerns, such as state or I/O, in a purely functional language. They structure programs as a sequence of computations by chaining functions that return wrapped values, abstracting away boilerplate code for side effects.

The CAP theorem states that a distributed data store cannot simultaneously provide more than two out of three guarantees: Consistency, Availability, and Partition Tolerance. This fundamental trade-off influences the design and selection of distributed systems like NoSQL databases under network partitions.

easy.text: Be the change you wish to see in the world. – Mahatma Gandhi
It always seems impossible until it's done. – Nelson Mandela
The only way to do great work is to love what you do. – Steve Jobs

medium.text: Two things are infinite: the universe and human stupidity; and I'm not sure about the universe. – Albert Einstein
The journey of a thousand miles begins with one step. – Lao Tzu
Man is condemned to be free; because once thrown into the world, he is responsible for everything he does. – Jean-Paul Sartre

hard.text: There is a theory which states that if ever anyone discovers exactly what the Universe is for and why it is here, it will instantly disappear and be replaced by something even more bizarre and inexplicable. There is another theory which states that this has already happened. – Douglas Adams
I would never die for my beliefs because I might be wrong. – Bertrand Russell
The most beautiful experience we can have is the mysterious. It is the fundamental emotion that stands at the cradle of true art and true science. – Albert Einstein

easy.text: We have ten fingers and ten toes. This is why we use a number system based on ten, called the decimal system.
A square has four equal sides and four right angles. A rectangle also has four angles, but its sides are not all the same length.
There are sixty seconds in one minute, and sixty minutes in one hour. This means there are three thousand six hundred seconds in an hour.

medium.text: The Fibonacci sequence starts with 0 and 1. Each following number is the sum of the two before it: 0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13. It appears often in nature, like in the arrangement of pinecone scales.
A prime number is a whole number greater than 1 that has no positive divisors other than 1 and itself. The first few primes are 2, 3, 5, 7, and 11. The number 2 is the only even prime number.
In probability, the chance of flipping a fair coin and getting 'heads' is one in two, or 0.5. The probability of rolling a six on a standard die is one in six, approximately 0.1667.

hard.text: Graham's number, a colossal upper bound in Ramsey theory, is so large that its last digits are impossible to compute using conventional mathematics. It is expressed using Knuth's up-arrow notation, a method for representing extremely large integers.

The Riemann Hypothesis, an unproven conjecture, states that all non-trivial zeros of the Riemann zeta function have a real part equal to 1/2. Its proof would have profound implications for the distribution of prime numbers.

Chaitin's constant (Ω) is a non-computable number representing the probability that a randomly constructed program will halt for a given universal Turing machine. It is a key concept in algorithmic information theory, embodying randomness in mathematics.
